editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE VIRGINIA ALMANACK For the YEAR of our LORD, 1790. BEING THE SECOND AFTER BISSEXTILE OR LEAP YEAR. Calculated to the Meridian of RICHMOND: AND WILL ANSWER ANY PART OF VIRGINIA OR NORTH-CAROLINA.

WHEREIN ARE CONTAINED, The LUNATIONS, CONJUNCTIONS, and ECLIPSES, the Ri≈øing and Setting of the SUN; Equation of Time; the Ri≈øing, Setting, Southing, Place, Age, and Pha≈øes of the MOON; true Places and A≈øpects of the PLANETS; remarkable Days, Weather, &c. together with a Variety of u≈øeful and entertaining Matter, calculated to improve the mind.
By BENJAMIN WORKMAN, M. A.
RICHMOND: PRINTED BY AUG. DAVIS, AT THE POST-OFFICE.

div.head: THE NAMES AND CHARACTERS OF THE SEVEN PLANETS.
div.p: ‚ôÑ Saturn, ‚ôÉ Jupiter, ‚ôÇ Mars, ‚òâ or üúî Sol, ‚ôÄ Venus, ‚òø Mercury, ‚òΩ or ‚ùç Luna.

div.head: THE FIVE ASPECTS.
div.p: ‚òå Conjunction, ‚òç Oppo≈øition, ‚Ä¢ trine; Trine, ‚ñ° Quartile, ‚öπ Sextile.

‚òû ALL the calculations in this Almanack are made for apparent time, or that deduced immediately from the Sun, either by ob≈øerving his pa≈ø≈øing the meridian, his ri≈øing or ≈øetting, or by the time ≈øhewn by a ≈øun-dial‚ÄîThis time differs from that ≈øhewn by well regulated clocks or watches, and the equation of time is their difference, which is given for every third day; its title ≈øhews whether the ≈øun is too fa≈øt or too ≈ølow, &c. The equation of time is of the utmo≈øt importance in regulating clocks and watches; ≈øo that a per≈øon ≈øetting his clock or watch by the Sun, ‚Ä¢ ther from his pa≈ø≈øing the meridan, from a good ≈øun-dial, or from his ri≈øing or ≈øetting, mu≈øt allow for the equation of time, otherwi≈øe his clock or watch is ju≈øt ≈øo much wrong; this in ≈øome months of the year amounts to more than a quarter of an hour; and of con≈øequence a very con≈øiderable mi≈øtake is introduced, where it is neglected.‚ÄîThe A≈øpects in≈øerted are the Conjunctions, Oppo≈øitions, and Square or Quartile A≈øpects of the Sun and Planets, as being the only cele≈øtial paenomena of any importance; but the Sextile and Trine A≈øpects are omitted, as of no utility, but in a≈øtrological impo≈øition. The two inferior Planets Venus and Mercury are ve≈øpertine (evening) ≈øtars after the ≈øuperior Conjunction; and matutine (morning) ≈øtars after the inferior Conjunction; when they have their greate≈øt elongation their ri≈øing and ≈øetting are at the greate≈øt di≈øtance before and after the Sun's; and this is the be≈øt time for ob≈øerving them; e≈øpecially Mercury, who≈øe motion is ≈øo rapid that he can only be ≈øeen for a few days at that time. From the time of the oppo≈øition to the conjunction of the ≈øuperior Planets, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn, they are ve≈øpertine ≈øtars, but from the conjunction to the oppo≈øition they are matutine ≈øtars: at the oppo≈øition they come to the meridian at midnight, and at the quartile a≈øpects they come to the meridian „Äà‚óä„Äâ 6 o'clock, either in the evening or morning according as they „Äà‚óä„Äâ ve≈øpertine or matutine ≈øtars.

div.head: II. FEBRUARY, 28 Days.
div.p: Venus is Evening Star until the 18th of March, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ Star from that day until the end of the year.

lg.l: COME youthful mu≈øe, my brea≈øt in≈øpire
With ≈øparks of true poetic fire,
To ≈øing of Hope, the only cure
Of all misfortunes men endure:
The captive's liberty, the ≈øick man's health,
The lover's victory, the beggar's copious wealth.
Thou ble≈ø≈øing ≈øent us from above;
Rich offspring of cele≈øtial love!
Fair Hope! thy pre≈øence let me hail,
When grief intrudes, when pains a≈ø≈øail.
O'er life's rough ≈øea, amid the tempe≈øts roar,
Pilot my rolling bark, and ≈øet me ≈øafe on ≈øhore.
'Tis thine, when troubles rack the heart,
Thy lenient bal≈øam to impart,
This load of life, oh! who could bear,
Did≈øt thou not ≈øwage each galling care.
Thy frowns all human happine≈øs de≈øtroy,
Thy ≈ømiles dawn peace and everla≈øting joy.
The wretch of every friend bereft,
By kindred ≈øcorned, by fortune left,
The orphan plunged in ≈øeas of care,
The widowed wife, the injured heir,
Through the dark cloud that interrupts thy blaze,
Perceive thy glimmering light, and own thy cheering rays.
Repents, ga≈øping out their breath,
And ≈øtruggling with convul≈øive death,
Friendly lift up their dying eyes,
While nature tells her pangs in ≈øighs;
To thee their ardent genuine wi≈øhes lend,
Implore thy healing aid, and in thee find a friend.
Supported by thy kindly hand,
The patriot in a ≈øinking land,
Anxious to prop the falling ≈øtate:
Smiles at fatigue, ≈øerenely great;
Retorts the dart of malice, truly brave,
And boldly ≈øtems the force of faction's waves.
The laws delay the lover's pain,
Oppre≈ø≈øion's whip, confinement's chain,
The ≈øcourge of pride and guilt's keen ≈ømart,
Would ≈øoon ≈øubdue the labouring heart;
But thou ≈øteps in the drooping ≈øoul to ea≈øe,
And giv'≈øt a future view of more delightful days.
ORDAIN'D to tread the thorny ground,
Where few, I fear, are faithful found;
Mine be the con≈øcience void of blame,
The upright heart, the ≈øpotle≈øs name;
The tribute of the widow's prayer,
The righted orphan's grateful tear;
To virtue and her friends, a friend,
Still may my voice the weak defend:
Ne'er may my pro≈øtituted tongue
Protect the oppre≈ø≈øor in his wrong:
Nor wre≈øt the ≈øpirit of the laws,
To ≈øanctify the villain's cau≈øe;
Let others, with un≈øparing hand,
Scatter their poi≈øon through the land;
Inflame di≈ø≈øention, kindle ≈øtrife,
And ≈øtrew with ills the path of life;
On ≈øuch, her gifts let fortune ≈øhower,
Add wealth to wealth, and pow'r to pow'r;
On me may favoring Heaven be≈øtow,
That peace which good men only know;
The joy of joy, by few po≈ø≈øe≈øt,
Th' eternal ≈øun≈øhine of the brea≈øt:
Pow'r, ‚Ä¢ ame, and riches I re≈øign,
The prai≈øe of hone≈øty be mine:
That friends may weep, the worthy ≈øigh,
And poor men ble≈øs me when I die.
AS rapid rolls the year away,
Down the ≈øwift current of the times,
A moment let the reader ≈øtay,
And mark the moral of my rhymes.
As rivers glide towards the ≈øea,
And ≈øink and lo≈øe them in the main,
So man declines‚Äîand what is he?
His hope, his wi≈øh, alas, how vain!
Fa≈øt goes the year, but ≈øtill renewed,
The ball of time knows no decay
Sure ≈øignal of that greate≈øt good,
We hope in God's eternal day.
OF earthly goods, the be≈øt is a good wife,
A bad, the bittere≈øt cur≈øe of human life.

div.head: LIBERTY AND SLAVERY.
div.p: DISGUISE thy≈øelf as thou wilt, ≈øtill, Slavery! ≈øtill thou art a bitter draught; and though thou≈øands in all ages have been made to drink of thee, thou art no le≈øs bitter on that account. It is thou, Liberty, thrice ≈øweet and gracious godde≈øs! whom all in public or in private wor≈øhip: who≈øe ta≈øte is grateful, and ever will be ≈øo, till nature her≈øelf ≈øhall change. No tint of words can ≈øpot thy ≈ønowy mantle, or chymic power turn thy ≈øceptre into iron. With thee to ≈ømile upon him as he eats his cru≈øt, the ≈øwain is happier than his monarch, from who≈øe court thou art exiled. Gracious Heaven! grant me but health, thou great be≈øtower of it; and give me but this fair godde≈øs as my companion, and ≈øhower down thy mitres, if it ≈øeem good unto thy providence, upon tho≈øe heads which are aching for them.

div.head: A GENERAL DESCRIPTION of AMERICA.
div.p: THIS great We≈øtern Continent, frequently denominated the New World, extends from the 80th Degree North to the 56th of South Latitude; and, where its breadth is known, from the 56th to the 136th Degree of We≈øt Longitude from London, ≈øtretching from between 8 and 9000 Miles in length, and in its greate≈øt breadth 36 ‚Ä¢ 0. It ≈øees both Hemi≈øpheres, has two Summers and a double Winter, and enjoys all the variety of Climates which the Earth affords. It is wa≈øhed by the two great Oceans; to the Ea≈øtward it has the Atlantic, which divides it from Europe and Africa; to the We≈øt, the Pacific or great South Sea, by which it is ≈øeparated from A≈øia: By the≈øe Seas it may, and does carry a direct Commerce with the other three parts of the World.

This great Continent is divided into two parts, one on the North, the other on the South, which are joined by the Kingdom of Mexico, forming a ≈øort of I≈øthmus 1500 Miles long, and in one part, at DARI ‚Ä¢ N, ≈øo extremely narrow, as to make the Cumminication between the two Oceans by no means difficult, being only 60 Miles. In the great Gulph which is formed between the I≈øthmus and the Northern and Southern grand divi≈øions of this Continent, lie an infinite multitude of I≈ølands, many of them large, mo≈øt of them fertile, and denominated the We≈øt-Indies, in contradiction to the Countries and I≈ølands of A≈øia, beyond the Cape of Good-Hope, which are called the Ea≈øt-Indies. The variety of u≈øeful and entertaining matter a publication of this ≈øort ought to contain, the limits to which we are confined will not admit of a particular de≈øcription of all the Countries contained in this va≈øt Continent.

div.head: UNITED STATES.
div.p: THE United States of America, under the pre≈øent government are eleven, New-Hamp≈øhire, Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts, Connecticut, New York, New-Jer≈øey, Penn≈øylvania, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, South-Carolina, and Georgia. Rhode-I≈øland and North-Carolina, no ‚Ä¢ having ratified the Federal Con≈øtitution.

The Declaration of Independence, by which the≈øe States took an equal ≈øtation among the nations of the earth, is dated July 4, 1776. The Articles of Confederation between ≈øaid States were finally ratified on the fir≈øt of March, 1781; and the territory granted to them, extends from Canada on the lakes to Florida; and from the Atlantic Ocean, to the river Mi≈ø≈øi≈øippi: It is about fourteen hundred miles in length, from northea≈øt to ≈øouthwe≈øt; and from ea≈øt to we≈øt, its breadth at the northern extremity, is about twelve hundred miles; but at the ≈øouthern, not more than ≈øeven hundred.
The northern part of this land is called the Province of Main, and belongs to the ≈øtate of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts.

div.head: NEW-HAMPSHIRE
div.p: Is a tract of land, originially carved out of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets. It lies on the ≈øouth ≈øide of the Pi≈øcataqua, between the ≈øea and Connecticut river. Its form is nearly that of a ≈øugar-loaf or pyramid, the ba≈øe of which ≈øtretches two hundred miles on Connecticut river. Is 180 miles in length, and 60 in breadth, contained, according to an enumeration in 1787, 102,000 inhabitants; ≈øituated between 4 ‚Ä¢ and 49 degrees North Latitude, and 67 and 72 We≈øt Longitude. Attached to the Federal Government, and engaged in organizing her militia, already the be≈øt di≈øciplined of any in the Union‚Äîencouraging the dome≈øtic arts, and looking forward to the benefits which will re≈øult from the operations of the New Con≈øtitution. New-Hamp≈øhire, from her local advantages, and the hardihood of her ≈øons, may anticipate e≈ø≈øential benefits from the operation of equal commercial regulations. The principal towns are, Port≈ømouth, the capital and ≈øeat of government, lying on Pi≈øcataway-Bay, where the large≈øt ≈øhips may ride in ≈øafety, and Exeter, a fine inland town, which was the ≈øeat of government during the late war.

div.head: MASSACHUSETTS
div.p:
Extends from the ocean on the ea≈øt, to the bounds of New-York on the we≈øt; it has Rhode-I≈øland and Connecticut on the ≈øouth, and New-Hamp≈øhire and Vermont on the north; is 450 miles in length, and 160 in breadth‚ñ™ contained, according to an enumeration in 1787. 360,000 inhabitants; ≈øituated between 42 and 45 degrees North Latitude, and 70 and 73 We≈øt Longitude. Since the tranquility of the ≈øtate was re≈øtored by the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of the late in≈øurrection, the whole body of the people appear ≈øolicitous for the ble≈ø≈øings of peace and good government. If any conclu≈øion can be drawn from elections to the Federal Legi≈ølature, this ≈øtate has a decided majority in favor of the New Con≈øtitution. The great objects of Commerce, Agriculture, Manufactures, and the Fi≈øheries, appear greatly to engage the attention of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts. Fabrications of Cotton, coar≈øe Woollens, Linens, Duck, Iron, Wood, &c. are pro≈øecuting with ≈øucce≈øs‚Äîand by dimini≈øhing her imports, and increa≈øing her exports, ≈øhe is advancing to that rank and importance in the Union, which her extent of territory, her re≈øources, and the genius and enterpri≈øe of her citizens entitle her to‚Äîand although the colli≈øion of parties, at the moment of election, ≈øtrikes out a few ≈øparks of animo≈øity, yet the deci≈øion once made, the "calumet of peace" is ≈ømoked in love and friend≈øhip, "and like true republicans they acquie≈øce in the choice of the majority." The principal towns are, Bo≈øton a large and populous city, ≈øituated on a penin≈øula, at the bottom of a large bay; it is elegant and well built, and de≈øervedly called the ≈øecond town in the United States: Newbury-Port, a flouri≈øhing ≈øea-port town; Falmouth, which was
burnt by the Engli≈øh at the beginning of the late war, and ri≈øing from its a≈øhes: and Charle≈øton, which was al≈øo laid in ruins, is now entirely re-built. A bridge covering Charles river, leads betwixt Bo≈øton and Charle≈øton, is more than 1300 feet in length, and the noble≈øt ≈øtructure in America. The Univer≈øity at Cambridge, is the fir≈øt literary in≈øtitution on the Continent. Its buildings are large and elegant‚Äîits literary and philo≈øophical apparatus are the mo≈øt complete of any in America.

div.head: CONNECTICUT
div.p: Is bounded by Rhode-I≈øland on the ea≈øt, by Long-I≈øland ≈øound on the ≈øouth, by Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts on the north, and New-York on the we≈øt; is 81 miles in length, and 57 in breadth, contained, agreeable to a cen≈øus in 1782, 209,150 inhabitants; ≈øituated between 41 and 43 degrees North Latitude, and 73 and 75 We≈øt Longitude. Enjoying a fertile ≈øoil, this truly republican ≈øtate is pur≈øuing her intere≈øt in the promotion of Manufactures, Commerce, Agriculture, and the Sciences‚Äî≈øhe appears to bid fair ‚Ä¢ from the peaceable, loyal, and federal character of the great body of her citizens‚Äîfrom the enterpri≈øe of her men of wealth, and other favorable circum≈øtances, to attain to a great degree of opulence, power, and re≈øpectability in the Union. The principal towns are. Hartford, a fine inland town on Connecticut river; and New-Haven, and New-London, two flouri≈øhing Sea-port towns.

The inhabitants of New England are mo≈øtly the de≈øcendents of the fir≈øt Engli≈øh ≈øettlers; there is no French. Dutch, or Germans, and very few Scotch and Iri≈øh. Including Vermont and Rhode-I≈øland (not in the Union) there is almo≈øt 10,000 inhabitants.

div.head: NEW-YORK
div.p: Extends from the ocean to Lake Champlain and Canada, and has Connecticut, Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts, and Vermont on the ea≈øt, and New-Jer≈øey and Penn≈øylvania on the We≈øt; is 350 miles in length, and 300 in breadth, contained, agreeably to a cen≈øus in 1786, 238 897 inhabitants; ≈øituate between 40 and 45 degrees North Latitude, and 74 and 76 We≈øt Longitude; enjoying a fertile ≈øoil. New-York is now ri≈øing greatly in her Federal Character, and in Manufacturing, Agricultural, and Commercial con≈øequence: Evidenced „Äà‚óä„Äâ Federal Elections‚Äîher plans for promoting Manufactures, and the increa≈øe of her exports. The principal towns are, New-York, ≈øituated on New-York i≈øland, at the confluence of the Ea≈øt and North rivers, an elegant and populous city, with an excellent harbour, now the re≈øidence of the Congre≈øs of the United States. Hud≈øon, lying on Hud≈øon's river, navigable for ≈øhips of almo≈øt any ≈øize, about 130 miles from New-York, and Albany a city on the North river, about thirty miles above Hud≈øon, built by the Dutch, and carries on a great for trade.

Columbia College in the city of New-York is well endowed and furni≈øhed with able Profe≈ø≈øors; and the New-York Chamber of Commerce is a very u≈øeful Mercantile Society, in≈øtituted for the purpo≈øes of promoting and encouraging Commerce, ≈øupporting Indu≈øtry, and adju≈øting di≈øputes relative to Trade and Navigation. They meet once in every month, to tran≈øact ≈øuch bu≈øine≈øs as may come before them, and e≈øtabli≈øh rules for the order and good government of the Society. There is al≈øo a Marine Society, for the purpo≈øes of improving Maritime knowledge, and for relieving the Wives and Children of decea≈øed Ma≈øters of Ve≈ø≈øels, not le≈øs worthy of imitation, that meet quarterly.

div.head: NEW-JERSEY
div.p: Has the river Hud≈øon and the ocean on the ea≈øt, and the Delaware on the we≈øt. It extends from Cape May at the entrance of the Delaware on the ≈øouth, to the limits of New-York ≈øtate, we≈øt of the Hud≈øon, about twenty miles from the mouth of that river; is 160 miles in length, and 52 in breadth, contained, by a cen≈øus in 1784, 149 435 inhabitants; ≈øituated between 30 and 42 degrees North Latitude, and 74 and 76 We≈øt Longitude. The inhabitants of this ≈øtate are warmly attached to the New Con≈øtitution‚Äîthe ble≈ø≈øings of peace and good government, being properly prized by them. The Arts and Sciences are objects of importance in this ≈øtate‚ñ™ and many of her ≈øons rank high in the republic of letters. The principal towns are, Trenton, a flouri≈øhing town near the Delaware; Burlington on the ≈øame river, in a healthy ≈øituation, enjoying great commercial privileges; Amboy, a ≈øea-port town on Hud≈øon's Bay, well ≈øituated for trade; New-Brun≈øwick a large inland town; and Princeton, a delightful ≈øituation, the ≈øeat of a College, called Na≈ø≈øau-Hall, which has produced a great number of eminent Scholars.

div.head: PENNSYLVANIA
div.p:
Extends from the Delaware on the ea≈øt, Maryland on the ≈øouth, New York on the north, and Virginia and Lake Eri on the we≈øt; is 288 miles in length, and 156 in breadth, contained by a cen≈øus in 1787, 360,000 inhabitants; ≈øituated between 39 and 44 degrees North Latitude, and 75 and 80 We≈øt Longitude. This exten≈øive and truly re≈øpectable ≈øtate is making great proficiency in her Manufactures. Agriculture, Arts and Commerce. Her attachment to the New Con≈øtitution is unequivocal, and with a con≈øi≈øtency highly honorary to her national character ≈øhe has lately made an effort (which though defeated for a time, will undoubtedly be ≈øucce≈øsful) to conform her ≈øtate con≈øtitution to that of the Union. The principal towns are Philadelphia the large≈øt and mo≈øt regular city in America ≈øituate on the river Delaware, enjoying an exten≈øive trade, the Univer≈øity in „Äà‚óä„Äâ city, is well endowed with
able Profe≈ø≈øors, as is al≈øo the Prote≈øtant Epi≈øcopal Academy; and here the Philo≈øophical Society meet in the hou≈øe of their Pre≈øident, the immortal Franklin. Carli≈øle, an inland town, where a flouri≈øh-≈øeminary of learning, called Dicken≈øon College, has been lately erected; Reading and York, are flouri≈øhing boroughs, as are al≈øo Germantown and Bri≈øtol; Lanca≈øter, another borough, is the large≈øt inland town in the United States, where is founded a German College called Franklin, after its principal benefactor; and Pitt≈øburgh ≈øituated on the confluence of the rivers Alleghany and Monongahela, increa≈øes rapidly, and bids fair to be the Emporium of the We≈øtern Country.

div.head: DELAWARE
div.p: Comprehends three counties only, which extends from Penn≈øylvania to the entrance of the river Delaware; is 92 miles in length, and 16 in breadth; contained, according to a cen≈øus in 1787, 87,000 inhabitants; ≈øituate between 38 and 40 degrees North Latitude, and 76 We≈øt Longitude. This ≈øtate though circum≈øcribed in its limits‚ñ™ derives great importance from its rank in the Union; attached to the New Con≈øtitution, and having the honor to take the lead in its adoption, there is no doubt of its giving efficacy to its righteous admini≈øtration. The principal towns are Wilmington ≈øituate on Chri≈øtians Greek, three miles from the Delaware; New Ca≈øtle, a ≈ømall town in the country of that name; Dover, the ≈øeat of government, and Newark, where is a ≈øeminary of Learning.

div.head: MARYLAND
div.p: Is bounded by Penn≈øylvania on the north, by the ocean on the ea≈øt, and by Virginia on the ≈øouth and we≈øt. It is divided into two parts called the ea≈øtern and we≈øtern ≈øhores, by the great bay of Che≈øapeake; is 134 miles in length, and 110 in breadth, contained by a cen≈øus in „Äà‚óä„Äâ 253,630 inhabitants; ≈øituated between 37 and 40 North Latitude and 75 and 79 We≈øt Longitude. From its favorable ≈øituation in the Union, this ≈øtate bids fair for pro≈øperity, wealth, and eminence. Warmly attached to the New Con≈øtitution, and enjoying a central ≈øituation. The principal towns are, Baltimore, which lies upon an arm of the Che≈øapeake, is a flouri≈øhing ≈øea-port town, which ri≈øes in wealth and ≈øize with amazing rapidity; Annapolis, the ≈øeat of government, an elegant town on the river Severn; St. Mary's, which has nothing remarkable but having once been the capital of the Province; Fredericktown, a fine flouri≈øhing inland town; and George-town, ≈øituate at the head of navigation on the river Patowmack ≈øeems to flouri≈øh in commercial con≈øequence. They have erected a College upon the ea≈øtern ≈øhore, called Wa≈øhington College, in honor of that illu≈øtrious character. There is al≈øo a College to be erected upon the we≈øtern ≈øhore.

div.head: VIRGINIA
div.p:
Is bounded by the Atlantic on the ea≈øt, by Maryland, Penn≈øylvania, and the Ohio, on the north; by the Mi≈ø≈øi≈øippi and Ohio on the we≈øt, and by North Carolina on the ≈øouth; is 758 miles in length, and 2 ‚Ä¢ 4 in breadth, contained, by a cen≈øus in 1782, 567,614 inhabitants; ≈øituate between 36 and 40 degrees North Latitude, and 75 and 90 We≈øt Longitude. From the natural ardour of her ≈øons in the cau≈øe of freedom, Virginia is frequently convul≈øed in her elections, and has been torn by factions‚ÄîPo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing an exten≈øive territory and va≈øt income, her funds are placed on a re≈øpectable footing; and as her repre≈øentation in the Federal Legi≈ølature, is decidedly in favor of the New Con≈øtitution, there is now no doubt but that ≈øhe will ≈øee her intere≈øt and glory finally connected with a few temporary ≈øacrifices upon the principles of mutual conce≈ø≈øion. The principal towns are, Richmond, the ≈øeat of government, ≈øituated at the falls of James' river, a flouri≈øhing town; Peter≈øburg, a flouri≈øhing town on the Appamattox river; William≈øburg, a fine well built city, has an Univer≈øity called William and Mary, which is well endowed; Norfolk, a port with the mo≈øt commodious harbour in the United States, and the large≈øt town in Virginia, it was burnt by the Engli≈øh at the beginning of the war in Virginia; and has now ri≈øen from its a≈øhes, and carries on a con≈øiderable trade; Port≈ømouth, is oppo≈øite Norfolk, and enjoys the ≈øame privileges; Alexandria, another port on the Patowmac river, within ten miles of the ≈øeat of the illu≈øtrious American hero, General WASHINGTON; Frederick≈øburg, another town on the Patowmac; Staunton, a pretty inland town beyond the Alleghany mountains. Virginia boa≈øts of ≈øome of the large≈øt and be≈øt rivers in America. On the north, the Patowmac, which divdes that ≈øtate from Maryland, ri≈øes in the Allegany mountains, bend „Äà‚óä„Äâ cour≈øe ≈øouth ea≈øt and falls into the Che≈øapeake. It has eighteen feet water at Alexandria, about one hundred and fifty miles from its mouth; and ten feet at George-town, eight miles higher. About five miles above are the falls, which ob≈øtruct the navigation for fifteen miles. The Rappahannock is a ≈ømall river, but affords twelve feet water to Frederick≈øburg, ju≈øt below the falls. York river furni≈øhes, at York town, a few miles from its mouth, the be≈øt harbour in the ≈øtate for ve≈ø≈øels of a large ≈øize. It holds four fathom water, twenty miles above York town. James' river admits ve≈ø≈øels of two hundred and fifty tons burthen to Warwick, and of one hundred and twenty-five tons to Richmond, about ninety „Äà‚óä„Äâ from its mouth. Nan≈øemond and Chickahominy affords water for ≈ømall ve≈ø≈øels, ≈øeveral miles into the country. Elizabeth river affords an excellent harbour and large enough for three hundred ≈øhips. At Norfolk it has eighteen feet water at common ‚Ä¢ ood tide. The Roanoke runs
through part of Virginia, and is navigable for boats. On the we≈øt of the Allegany mountains are the great and little Kanawa, which ri≈øe in the mountains, and run north-we≈øt into the Ohio.‚ÄîThe Monongahela is one principal branch of the Ohio. The ≈øource of this river is ≈øeparated from the Patowmac by the Allegany Ridge. The di≈øtance is about forty miles.‚ÄîThe river Allegany is the other principal branch of the Ohio. The head of the river is but fifteen miles di≈øtant from Pre≈øque I≈ø≈øe on Lake Erie. The rivers Cumberland, Cherooke, and Kentucky, waters the we≈øtern part of Virginia, furni≈øhing navigation for batteaux into the heart of the country. Virginia is de≈øervedly confe≈ø≈øed without all manner of doubt, the mo≈øt convenient country in the world for navigation.
‚ÅÇ In line 26, of the preceding page, for Frederick≈øburg, another town on the 'PATOWMAC,' read on the 'RAPPAHANNOCK.'

div.head: SOUTH-CAROLINA
div.p: Has North-Carolina on the north, the ocean on the ea≈øt, Georgia on the ≈øouth and Mi≈ø≈øi≈øippi on the we≈øt; is 200 miles in length, and 125 in breadth‚ñ™ contained by a cen≈øus in 1787, 180,000 inhabitants; ≈øituate between 32 and 35 degrees North Latitude, and 79 and 90 We≈øt Longitude; an important member of the Union, has appeared lately to vibrate between oppo≈øing ≈øentiments‚Äîher attachment to national mea≈øures we doubt not will evidently di≈øcover it≈øelf when all tender laws and pine barreus ≈øhall be done away. The prohibition of the importation of ≈ølaves, and the provi≈øion lately made for the reduction of her foreign debt, to which may be added, the determination of that ≈øtate to call a Convention to adopt their ≈øtate con≈øtitution to that of the Union, are truly Federal traits. The principal towns are. Charle≈øton, the capital and ≈øeat of government, ≈øituated at the confluence of the rivers A≈øhley and Cooper, it is large and elegant; and Beaufort, another ≈øeaport town.

div.head: GEORGIA
div.p:
Is bounded by South-Carolina on the north, by the Atlantic on the ea≈øt; by Ea≈øt and We≈øt Florida on the ≈øouth, and by Mi≈ø≈øi≈øipp ‚Ä¢ on the we≈øt; is 600 miles in length, and 250 in breadth; contained, according to a cen≈øus in 1787, 98,000 inhabitants; ≈øituated between 30 and 33 degrees North Lat. and 76 and 90 We≈øt Longitude. This ≈øtate has completed her Federal Character by conforming her ≈øtate con≈øtitution to that of the Union‚Äîand being the younge≈øt branch of the Family, and a frontier, ≈øhe will doubtle≈øs experience the ≈øupporting and protecting arm of the Federal Government. The principal towns are, Savannah, the capital, a fine commercial town on the river of the ≈øame name; Sunbury, a ≈øea-port, very well ≈øituated for trade; and Augu≈øta, ≈øituated at the
head of navigation on the river Savannah, one hundred and thirty four miles from the ≈øea, is the ≈øeat of government.
NORTH-CAROLINA

Is bounded by Virginia on the North, the Atlantic on the Ea≈øt, by South Carolina on the South, and by the Mi≈ø≈øi≈øippi on the We≈øt; is 758 miles in length, and 110 in breadth; contained, agreeable to a cen≈øus in 1787, 270,000 inhabitants; ≈øituated between 35 and 37 degrees North Latitude, and 76 and 90 We≈øt-Longitude. This ≈øtate has again called a Convention for the purpo≈øe of adopting the New Con≈øtitution, nor is there now any doubt that when the mild yet efficient operations of the New Government, together with the wi≈ødom and patrioti≈øm of the members of the Federal Legi≈ølature, are duly con≈øidered, it will remove every doubt of tho≈øe with who≈øe opinions it may not entirely coincide; and confirm the expectations of its numerous friends. And her exten≈øive frontier being obliged to export the greater part of her producttions through Virginia, there is no doubt, has fully evinced the nece≈ø≈øity of her acceding to the confederation, as a depreciated paper medium is con≈øidered as the principal cau≈øe of the anti-national ≈øpirit of this ≈øtate. The principal towns are, Newbern, Halifax, Edenton, Wa≈øhington, Fayetteville, Wilmington and Hil≈øborough.

div.head: RHODE-ISLAND
div.p: Including the i≈øland of that name and Providence Plantations, is bounded on the North by Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts-Bay, on the Ea≈øt by the Atlantic, on the We≈øt by Connecticut, and on the South by the Atlantic; is 68 miles in length, and 40 in breadth, contained, according to a cen≈øus in 1783, 51, 896 inhabitants. This ≈øtate has refu≈øed to accede to a union with her ≈øi≈øter ≈øtates, and is now almo≈øt wholly e≈øtranged from them; and from appearance will continue ≈øo, unle≈øs the mea≈øure of the iniquity of her "know ye" gentry ≈øhould be ≈øpeedily filled up‚Äîor the delu≈øion which has ≈øo long infatuated a majority of her citizens, ≈øhould be removed‚ÄîAnxious of enjoying the protection of the Union, the inhabitants of Newport, Providence and other places, are determined to ≈øue for its protection, and to be annexed to Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts or Connecticut. This di≈ømemberment of the ≈øtate it is to be de≈øired, may be prevented by her being wholly graffed into that ≈øtock from whence through blindne≈øs ≈øhe has been broken off. The principal towns are, Newport, the capital, ≈øituate on Rhode-I≈øland, which has an excellent harbour; and Providence, ≈øituated at the head of navigation on a large river or arm of the ≈øea, thirty miles from Newport, at pre≈øent in a flouri≈øhing condition. The bu≈øine≈øs of this ≈øtate con≈øi≈øts principally in the Whale Fi≈øhing and We≈øt-India trade.

div.head: Extracts from the AMERICAN JEST BOOK.
div.p: SOME years ago, immediately after the ≈øhock of a tremendous earthquake had alarmed the inhabitants of Grenada, the conver≈øation turned at the governor's table, upon the latent occa≈øion of the above phaenomenon; after every one of the company had a≈ø≈øigned it to a different cau≈øe, an old negro woman was a≈øked, what was her opinion on the ≈øubject; ≈øhe replied, "≈øhe thought the great God was pa≈ø≈øing by, and the earth had made him a curte≈øy."
A gentleman met another in the ≈øtreet, who was ill of a con≈øumption, and acco≈øted him thus‚Äî"Ah! my friend, you walk exceedingly flow"‚Äî"Yes (replied the ≈øick man) but I am going very fa≈øt."

A gentleman and his man riding into the country, they met a fellow a≈øtride upon a cow. The man calls cut to his ma≈øter, O, ≈øir, ≈øays he‚ñ™ yonder is a ≈øtrange ≈øight! a fellow is on hor≈øeback on a cow. That's a bull ≈øaid the gentleman. Nay, ≈øir, ≈øaid the man, it is not a bull, I know it is a cow by its teats.
A per≈øon bought a pair of horns and brought them home; his wife a≈øked what he meant? he ≈øaid to hang his hat on. Good lord‚ñ™ ≈øays ≈øhe, cannot you keep your hat on your own head?

Colonel Bond, who had been one of king Charles the fir≈øt's judges died a day or two before Cromwell, and it was ≈øtrongly reported every where, that the protector was dead; "No" ≈øays a gentleman, who knew better, "he has only given bond to the devil for his future appearance."

If you marry (≈øaid a father to his daughter) you will do well; if you do not marry, you will do better. If that's the ca≈øe, replied the daughter, "get me a hu≈øband as ≈øoon as you can, I ≈øhall be content to do well, and leave it to others to do better."
A judge, ≈øu≈øpected of bribery, checked his clerk, for having a dirty face. I plead guilty, my lord, ≈øaid the clerk, but my hands are clean.

The following example of laudable pride in a ≈øoldier, was mentioned in a letter from an officer of the American army, written ≈øoon after the battle of Monmouth.‚ÄîA ≈øoldier in that memorable action, fell into the hands of the Engli≈øh cavalry, when one of them knocked him down, and attempted to pierce him through the back with his ≈øword,‚Äî"Strike me in the heart," ≈øaid he, turning bri≈økly about "that my friends may not blu≈øh for me after my death."

An hone≈øt clergyman in the country was reproving a married couple for their frequent di≈ø≈øen≈øions, which were very unbecoming both in the eye of God and man, ≈øeeing that you are both one; Both one! cried the hu≈øband, were you to come by our door ≈øometimes when we quarrel, you would ≈øwear we were twenty.

A ≈øoldier in the late war having ≈øtolen a ≈øhirt from a farmer, to whom he would not make re≈øtitution‚Äî"Well, (≈øaid the farmer) if you keep it, you will pay for it in this world or in the next.‚Äî"Faith, (replied the ≈øoldier) if you will tru≈øt ≈øo long, I will take another."

An hone≈øt Jack Tar being at a quaker's meeting, heard the friend that was holding forth ≈øpeak with great emotion, again≈øt the ill con≈øequence of giving the lie in conver≈øation, and therefore he advi≈øed, when a man was telling a tale, that was not con≈øi≈øtent with truth or probability, to cry twang, which would not irritate the pa≈ø≈øions as the lie would. After digre≈ø≈øing into the ≈øtory of the great miracle of five thou≈øand being fed with five loaves of bread &c he told them that they were not ≈øuch loaves as are u≈øed now, but were as big as a mountain; at the hearing of which the tar uttered with a loud voice, twang! What, ≈øays the quaker, do≈øt thou think I lie, friend? No, ≈øays Jack, but I am thinking how big the ovens were that baked them.

Two gentlemen having a di≈øpute about religion, one ≈øaid to the other, I wonder, ≈øir, you ≈øhould talk of religion, when I'll hold you ten guineas you can't ≈øay the Lord's Prayer. Done ≈øaid the other. The money was depo≈øited and the gentleman began with, I believe in God, and ≈øo went cleverly through the creed: Well ≈øaid the other, I own I have lo≈øt; I did not think he could have done it.

Dr. Sheridan‚ñ™ the celebrated friend of Swift, had a cu≈øtom of ringing his ≈øcholars to prayers in his ≈øchool room, at a certain hour every day. The boys were one day very devoutly at prayers except one, who was ≈øtifling a laugh as well as he could; which aro≈øe from ≈øeeing a rat de≈øcending from the bell-rope into the room. The poor boy could hold out no longer, but bur≈øt into an immoderate fit of laughter, which ≈øet the others agoing when he pointed to the cau≈øe. Sheridan was ≈øo provoked, that he declared he would whip them all if the principal culprit was not pointed out to him;
which was immediately done. The poor pupil of Momus was immediately hoi≈øted, and his po≈øteriors laid bare to the rod, when the witty ≈øchoolma≈øter told him, if he ≈øaid any thing tolerable on the occa≈øion, as he looked on him as the greate≈øt dunce in his ≈øchool, he would forgv ‚Ä¢ him. The trembling culprit, with very little he≈øitation addre≈ø≈øed his ma≈øter with the following beautiful distich:
There was a rat‚Äîfor want of ≈øtairs,
Came down a rope‚Äîto go to pray'rs.
Sheridan in≈øtantly dropped the rod, and in≈øtead of a whipping gave him half a crown.

div.head: Sir WALTER RAWLEIGH's Letter to his Wife, after his condemnation.
div.p: "YOU ≈øhall receive, my dear wife, my la≈øt words in the≈øe my la≈øt lines. My love I ≈øend you that you may keep when I am dead; and my coun≈øel, that you may remember when I am no more. I would not with my will, pre≈øent you ≈øorrows, dear Be≈øs; let them go to the grave with me, and be buried in the du≈øt; and ≈øeeing that it is not the will of God that I ≈øhall ≈øee you any more, bear my de≈øtruction patiently; and with an heart like your≈øelf. Fir≈øt I ≈øend you all the thanks, which my heart can conceive, or my words expre≈øs, for your many travels and cares for me; which though they have not taken effect, as you wi≈øhed, yet my debt to you is not the le≈øs; but pay it I never ≈øhall in the world. Secondly, I be≈øeech you, for the love you „Äà‚óä„Äâ me living, that you do not hide your≈øelf many days; but by your travels ≈øeek to help my mi≈øerable fortunes, and the right of your poor child; your mourning cannot avail me who am but du≈øt. Thirdly, you ≈øhall under≈øtand that my lands were conveyed (bonafide) to my child; the writings were drawn at mid≈øummer was a twelve month, as divers can witne≈øs; and I tru≈øt, my blood will quench their malice, who de≈øired my ≈ølaughter, that they will not ≈øeek to kill you and yours with extreme poverty. To what friend to direct you, I know not: for all mine have left me in the true time of trial. Mo≈øt ≈øorry am I, that being ≈øurpri≈øed by death, I can leave you no better e≈øtate; God hath prevented all my determinations, that great God, which worketh all in all. If you can live free from want, care for no more; for the re≈øt is but a vanity. Love God, and begin betimes; in him ≈øhall you find true, everla≈øting and endle≈øs comfort; when you have travelled, and wearied your≈øelf with all ≈øorts of wordly cogitations, you ≈øhall ≈øit down with ≈øorrow in the end. Teach your ≈øon al≈øo to ≈øerve and fear God, whil≈øt he is young, that

div.p: the fear of God may grow up in him; then will God be an hu≈øband to you, and a father to him; an hu≈øband and a father that ≈øhall never be taken from you. Dear wife, I be≈øeech you for my ≈øoul's ≈øake, ‚Ä¢ ay all poor men, when I am dead, no doubt you will be much ≈øought unto; for the world thinks I was very rich: Have a care of the fair pretences of men; for no greater mi≈øery can befal you in this life, than to become a prey unto the world, and after to be de≈øpi≈øed. As for me, I am no more yours, nor you mine; death hath cut us a≈øunder; and God hath divided me from the world, and you from me. Remember your poor child, for his father's ≈øake, who loved you in his happie≈øt e≈øtate. I ≈øued for my life, but (God knows) it was for you and yours, that I de≈øired it; for know it, my dear wife, your child, is the child of a true man, who in his own re≈øpect de≈øpi≈øeth death, and his mi≈øhapen and ugly forms. I cannot write much; God knows, how hardly I ≈øteal this time, when all are a≈øleep: And it is al≈øo time for me to ≈øeparate my thoughts from the world. Beg my dead body, which living was denied you; and either lay it in Sherburne, or Exeter Church, by my father and mother. I can ≈øay no more; time and death call me away. The everla≈øting God, powerful, infinite and in≈øcrutable, God Almighty, who is goodne≈øs it≈øelf, the true light and life, keep you and yours, and have mercy upon me, and forgive my per≈øecutors, and fal≈øe accu≈øers; and ≈øend us to meet in his glorious Kingdom. My dear wife, farewell; ble≈øs my boy, pray for me: and let my true God hold you both in his arms.

closer.signed: Your's that was, but not now my own, WALTER RAWLEIGH.

div.p: A very pious Gentleman, but rather worldly, who lives not many miles from Bo≈øton, made it his con≈øtant practice to call up his family before day, in order that they might attend prayers and be ready for their labour in good ≈øea≈øon: One morning having mu≈øtered his family rather earlier than common, he commenced family duties by prayer, during which he returned thanks to the Lord, that they were brought to ≈øee the light of another day: an old negro ≈øtanding by, cried out, "Top, top, vate a bit, no day yet, ma≈ø≈øa, ≈øartin, no day yet."
